channel.title: A threat to Google
channel.description: It's very easy to get caught up in the Android versus iPhone duel and Google's recruiting battles with its newly-public Silicon Valley neighbor, Facebook. But neither one of those companies worry Google executives as much as another that is actively taking money out of their pockets. This company is from Washington, but no, it's not Microsoft. Google's real rival, and real competition to watch over the next few years is Amazon. Google is a search company, but the searches that it actually makes money from are the searches people do before they are about to buy something online. These commercial searches make up about 20 percent of total Google searches. Those searches are where the ads are. What Googlers worry about in private is a growing trend among consumers to skip Google altogether, and to just go ahead and search for the product they would like to buy on Amazon.com, or, on mobile in an Amazon app. There's data to prove this trend is real. According to ComScore, Amazon search queries are up 73 percent in the last year. But it makes intuitive sense doesn't it? Why go through these steps … Google search "rubber galoshes," Analyze some text links, Click on one to go to a product page on some e-commerce store, Click to add the item to your cart, Input your credit card, Input your address, … when you can just … Search amazon for "rubber galoshes," Click one button to buy the product with your usual credit card and have it shipped to your normal address. On mobile, where Amazon has its own app and Google is just a search bar for a smaller-screened browser, the equation tips further in Amazon's balance. The scenario gets even scarier for Google if Kindle phones and Kindle tablets gain ubiquity. If you have a Kindle phone, which comes with free movies and books because you have an Amazon Prime account, which also gives you free shipping, why in the WORLD would you ever search to buy something through anything but Amazon? You wouldn't. That's why Amazon is practically giving its hardware away. It's also why Amazon scares Google more than anything Facebook or Apple are up to.

item.title: A threat to Google
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:21, topic:454866”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=557732.msg4082733#msg4082733 date=1345503076]

Google has grown to much more than just a search engine though, I don’t think it matters if the search engine in particular is declining in usage considering android is the most popular mobile OS in the world now (and is on the rise), and Google Chrome has recently overtaken IE in usage figures.
[/quote]the only reason why IE has a large number is because computer idiots use IE until somebody tells them the truth about their crapp

That, and the fact that organisations like schools and colleges will have it installed as default, and disable the installation of any other browser. I imagine that participates to a fair chunk of the statistics.

Idk about disabling the installation but they definetly leave it as default. They do it partly because the school system signs an agreement with Microsoft for cheaper Microsoft Office stuff.

Well they definitely do here in England, or at least in the schools and colleges I’ve been taught at. Any .MSI installation files, or any applications that try to make changes to the system require admin rights to install

You sure that’s not just security set up by the school system to prevent viruses from being installed?

Well yes essentially, but in doing that they disable the execution of any unknown .exe files or any form of installation files, therefore a choice of different web browsers is not possible for the users with standard access rights[/quote]

I doubt Microsoft is behind that.

Read full topic

Google has grown to much more than just a search engine though, I don’t think it matters if the search engine in particular is declining in usage considering android is the most popular mobile OS in the world now (and is on the rise), and Google Chrome has recently overtaken IE in usage figures.
[/quote]the only reason why IE has a large number is because computer idiots use IE until somebody tells them the truth about their crapp

That, and the fact that organisations like schools and colleges will have it installed as default, and disable the installation of any other browser. I imagine that participates to a fair chunk of the statistics.

Idk about disabling the installation but they definetly leave it as default. They do it partly because the school system signs an agreement with Microsoft for cheaper Microsoft Office stuff.

Well they definitely do here in England, or at least in the schools and colleges I’ve been taught at. Any .MSI installation files, or any applications that try to make changes to the system require admin rights to install

You sure that’s not just security set up by the school system to prevent viruses from being installed?[/quote]
Well yes essentially, but in doing that they disable the execution of any unknown .exe files or any form of installation files, therefore a choice of different web browsers is not possible for the users with standard access rights

item.description:
@ggallin wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:2, topic:454866”]That’s very, very interesting.

However, I don’t think google will die any time soon.[/quote]

[quote=“m1lkman, post:10, topic:454866”][quote author=ggallin link=topic=557732.msg4080833#msg4080833 date=1345349394]
google is an ultra-super-mega-beast-power-whore-electricity-monger that controls 6.4% of the entire internet population. explain to me further your logic in how it will die.
[/quote]

Someone said it was going to die? Who? What? Where?[/quote]
i dunno, maybe it’s his imagination. I just followed from there

Read full topic

item.title: A threat to Google
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:11, topic:454866”]Amazon has been out longer ( I believe so…) they have gone through a couple of different management officers from what I am seeing on Google.(ironic? )

I don’t believe they can ever touch Google though. Hell, for that matter Windows/Microsoft made “bing” thinking it would drive Google away and Google just laughed.[/quote]

I don’t think bing was meant to drive Google away. Microsoft always has to have competition out there. Netscape makes JavaScript, Microsoft answers with JScript. Adobe buys out Macromedia Dreamweaver, Microsoft creates Expression Web. Microsoft likes to have its fingers in everything.

Read full topic
